article.title: CAMDLES: CFD-DEM Simulation of Microbial Communities in Spaceflight and Artificial Microgravity
funding: Space Biology program of NASA’s Biological and Physical Sciences (BPS) Division through the Space Life Sciences Training Program (SLSTP)
article.abstract: We present CAMDLES (CFD-DEM Artificial Microgravity Developments for Living Ecosystem Simulation), an extension of CFDEM Coupling to model biological flows, growth, and mass transfer in artificial microgravity devices.

sections.introduction: Microbial communities are an integral part of space exploration: they accompany human crew in habitats such as the International Space Station [1] and they will ultimately be used for bioregenerative life support [2], food and pharmaceuticals production [3], and in situ resource utilization [4].
sections.methods: CAMDLES is dependent on parent software packages to run simulations. Installation involves the addition of the package into the source code of the packages LIGGGHTS and CFDEM Coupling.
sections.results: For the first set of CAMDLES simulations, we tested the hypothesis that co-localization is necessary to enable high growth rates in the simplest environment: no gravity force.
sections.discussion: In this study, we used CFD-DEM modeling to investigate the relationship between the physical environment and the ecological interactions in a microbial community.

experimental_factors.treatment: artificial microgravity, spaceflight microgravity, 1 g conditions
experimental_factors.treatment_raw: artificial microgravity, spaceflight microgravity, and 1 g conditions

article.insights_summary: We present CAMDLES, an extension of CFDEM Coupling to model biological flows, growth, and mass transfer in artificial microgravity devices. Our simulations found that artificial microgravity has an amplifying effect on mass transfer and metabolite uptake compared to microgravity and a diminishing effect on sedimentation compared to 1 g gravity.
article.acknowledgments: We thank Will Harcombe and Jeremy Chacón (University of Minnesota) for providing growth and yield parameters for the microbial species and general guidance in understanding their biology.
